That's a fantastic attitude! Recording yourself dancing can be a game-changer for improving your technique. It's amazing how much you can learn from watching yourself from an outside perspective. You'll be able to see things like:

* Your posture and alignment: Are you standing up straight or slouching? Are your shoulders relaxed or tensed up?
* Your footwork and timing: Are you executing the steps correctly? Are you on beat or off?
* Your arm and hand placement: Are your arms relaxed and soft, or stiff and awkward?
* Your facial expressions and overall energy: Are you smiling and having fun, or looking tense and serious?

By watching yourself, you'll be able to identify areas where you need to improve and work on making adjustments. It's also a great way to track your progress over time and see how far you've come.

When you're recording yourself, try to focus on specific aspects of your dancing, like your pirouettes or jazz turns. You can even record yourself doing the same routine multiple times, trying out different approaches or adjustments each time. This will help you to refine your technique and develop muscle memory.

Remember, the goal is to learn and improve, not to criticize yourself. Be kind to yourself, and don't be afraid to make mistakes. It's all part of the learning process!

Also, consider sharing your videos with a dance instructor or a friend who's knowledgeable about dance. They may be able to provide you with additional feedback and suggestions for improvement.

Keep me posted on how it goes, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need any further guidance!
